Imperial Dome of Edward wise and brave!</br>Where warlike honour's brightest banners wave;</br>At whose proud Tilts, unmatch'd for hardy deeds,</br>Heroic kings have frown'd on barbed steeds:</br>Though now no more thy crested chiefs advance</br>In arm'd array, nor grasp the glittering lance;</br>Though knighthood boasts the martial pomp no more</br>That grac'd it's gorgeous festivals of yore;</br>Say, conscious Dome, if e'er thy marshal'd knights</br>So nobly deck'd their old majestic rites,</br>As when, high-thron'd amid thy trophied Shrine,</br>GEORGE shone the leader of the garter'd line?

Yet future triumphs, Windsor, still remain;</br>Still may thy bowers receive as brave a train:</br>For lo, to Britain and her Favour'd Pair,</br>Heaven's high command has sent a sacred Heir!</br>Him the bold pattern of his patriot sire</br>Shall fill with early fame's immortal fire:</br>In life's fresh spring, e'er buds the promis'd prime,</br>His thoughts shall mount to virtue's meed sublime:</br>The patriot fire shall catch, with sure presage,</br>Each liberal omen of his opening age;</br>Then to thy courts shall lead, with conscious joy,</br>In stripling beauty's bloom the princely boy;</br>There firmly wreathe the Braid of heavenly die,</br>True valour's badge, around his tender thigh.</br>Meantime, thy royal piles that rise elate</br>With many an antique tower, in massy state,</br>In the young champion's musing mind shall raise</br>Vast images of Albion's elder days.</br>While, as around his eager glance explores</br>Thy chambers rough with war's constructed stores,</br>Rude helms, and bruised shields; barbaric spoils</br>Of ancient chivalry's undaunted toils;</br>Amid the dusky trappings, hung on high</br>Young Edward's sable-mail shall strike his eye:</br>Shall fire the youth, to crown his riper years</br>With rival Cressys, and a new Poitiers;</br>On the same wall, the same triumphal base,</br>His own victorious monuments to place.

Nor can a fairer kindred title move</br>His emulative age to glory's love</br>Than Edward, laureate prince.  In letter'd truth,</br>Oxford, sage mother, school'd his studious youth</br>Her simple institutes and rigid lore,</br>The royal nursling unreluctant bore;</br>Nor shunn'd, at pensive eve, with lonesome pace</br>The moonlight cloyster's checquer'd floor to trace;</br>Nor scorn'd to mark the sun, at mattins due,</br>Stream through the storied window's holy hue.</br>And O, Young Prince, be thine his moral praise;</br>Nor seek in fields of blood his warriour bays.</br>War has it's charms terrific.  Far and wide</br>When stands th' embattled host in banner'd pride;</br>O'er the vext plain when the shrill clangours run,</br>And the long phalanx flashes in the sun;</br>When now no dangers of the deathful day</br>Mar the bright scene, nor break the firm array;</br>Full oft, too rashly glows with fond delight</br>The youthful breast, and asks the future fight;</br>Nor knows that Horror's form, a spectre wan,</br>Stalks, yet unseen, along the gleamy van.</br>May no such rage be thine:  No dazzling ray</br>Of specious fame thy stedfast feet betray.</br>Be thine domestic glory's radiant Calm,</br>Be thine the scepter wreath'd with many a palm;</br>Be thine the throne with peaceful emblems hung,</br>The silver lyre to milder conquest strung!</br>Instead of glorious feats atchiev'd in arms,</br>Bid rising Arts display their mimic charms:</br>Just to thy country's fame, in tranquil days</br>Record the past, and rouze to future praise:</br>Before the public eye, in breathing brass,</br>Bid thy fam'd father's mighty triumphs pass:</br>Swell the broad arch with haughty Cuba's fall,</br>And cloath with Minden's plain th' historic hall.

Then mourn not, Edward's Dome, thine ancient boast,</br>Thy turnaments, and listed combats lost!</br>From Arthur's Board, no more, proud castle, mourn</br>Adventurous valour's gothic trophies torn!</br>Those elfin charmes, that held in magic night</br>It's elder fame, and dimm'd it's genuine light,</br>At length dissolve in truth's meridian ray,</br>And the bright Order bursts to perfect day:</br>The mystic round, begirt with bolder peers,</br>On virtue's base it's rescued glory rears;</br>Sees civil prowess mightier acts atchieve,</br>Sees meek humanity distress relieve;</br>Adopts the Worth that bids the conflict cease,</br>And claims it's honours from the Chiefs of Peace.</br>
